sen.j: 歌川 広重（うたがわ ひろしげ、寛政9年（1797年） - 安政5年9月6日 (旧暦)（1858年10月12日）は、浮世絵師。
sen.e: Hiroshige UTAGAWA (1797 - October 12, 1858) was an Ukiyoe artist.
Hiroshige UTAGAWA (1797 - October 12, 1858) was an Ukiyoe artist.
Hiroshige UTAGAWA (1797 - October 12, 1858) was an Ukiyoe artist.

sen.j: 江戸の町火消しの安藤家に生まれ家督を継ぎ、その後に浮世絵師となった。
sen.e: He was born in the Ando family, firefighters in Edo, and after succeeding to the family headship, became an Ukiyoe artist.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He was born in the Ando family, who were firefighters in Edo, and after succeeding to the family headship, became an Ukiyoe artist.
He was born in the Ando family, who were firefighters in Edo, and after succeeding to the family headship, became an Ukiyoe artist.

sen.j: しかし、現代広く呼ばれる安藤広重（あんどう ひろしげ）なる名前は使用しておらず、浮世絵師としては歌川広重が正しいと言える。
sen.e: However, he did not use the name of Hiroshige ANDO as commonly called nowadays, and thus Hiroshige UTAGAWA is considered to be his right name as Ukiyoe artist.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, he did not use the name Hiroshige ANDO as he is commonly called nowadays, and thus Hiroshige UTAGAWA is considered to be his correct name as an Ukiyoe artist.
However, he did not use the name Hiroshige ANDO as he is commonly called nowadays, and thus Hiroshige UTAGAWA is considered to be his correct name as an Ukiyoe artist.

sen.j: 広重は、江戸の下級武士・八代洲河岸火消屋敷の同心、安藤源右衛門の子として誕生。
sen.e: Hiroshige was born as a son of Genemon ANDO, lower-ranking samurai in Edo and officer of Yayosu Riverbank Fire Station.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Hiroshige was born as a son of Genemon ANDO, a lower-ranking samurai in Edo and an officer of the Yayosu Riverbank Fire Station.
Hiroshige was born as a son of Genemon ANDO, a lower-ranking samurai in Edo and an officer of the Yayosu Riverbank Fire Station.

sen.j: 幼名徳太郎、のち重右衛門また徳兵衛とも称す。
sen.e: His childhood name was Tokutaro, and later Juemon or Tokube.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: His childhood name was Tokutaro, and later Juemon or Tokube.
His childhood name was Tokutaro, and later Juemon or Tokube.

sen.j: 幼い頃から絵心が勝り、文化 (元号)8年（1811年）（15歳）頃、はじめ初代歌川豊国の門に入ろうとしたが、門生満員でことわられた。
sen.e: He had been interested in painting from his childhood, and around 1811, at the age of 15, tried to enter the school of Toyokuni UTAGAWA the first, but was refused because there was no vacancy.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He had been interested in painting since childhood, and around 1811, at the age of 15, tried to enter the school of Toyokuni UTAGAWA the first, but was refused because there was no vacancy.
He had been interested in painting since childhood, and around 1811, at the age of 15, tried to enter the school of Toyokuni UTAGAWA at first, but was refused because there was no vacancy.

sen.j: そして歌川豊廣（1773年?-1828年）に入門、翌文化9年（1812年）に歌川廣重の名を与えられた。
sen.e: He then became a disciple of Toyohiro UTAGAWA (1773? - 1828) who gave him the name of Hiroshige UTAGAWA in the following year, 1812.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He then became a disciple of Toyohiro UTAGAWA (1773? - 1828) who gave him the name of Hiroshige UTAGAWA in the following year, 1812.
He then became a disciple of Toyohiro UTAGAWA (c. 1773 - 1828) who gave him the name of Hiroshige UTAGAWA in the following year, 1812.

sen.j: 11年後の文政6年（1823年）には、家業の火消同心を辞め、絵師を専門の職業にした。
sen.e: Eleven years later, in 1823, he resigned from the family business as fire fighter and became a full-time painter.
Eleven years later, in 1823, he resigned from the family business as a fire fighter and became a full-time painter.
Eleven years later, in 1823, he resigned from the family business as a fire fighter and became a full-time painter.

sen.j: 天保元年（1830年）一幽斎廣重と改め、花鳥を描いていたが、文政11年（1828年）師の豊廣の死の後は風景画を主に制作した。
sen.e: In 1830, he changed his name to Hiroshige ICHIYUSAI, painting flowers and birds, but after the death of Toyohiro in 1828 painted mainly landscapes.
In 1830, he changed his name to Hiroshige ICHIYUSAI, and began painting flowers and birds, but after the death of Toyohiro in 1828 he painted mainly landscapes.
In 1830, he changed his name to Hiroshige ICHIYUSAI, and began painting flowers and birds, but after the death of Toyohiro in 1828 he painted mainly landscapes.

sen.j: 天保3年 （1832年）、一立齋（いちりゅうさい）と号を改めた。
sen.e: In 1832, he changed his pseudonym to Ichiryusai.
In 1832, he changed his pseudonym to Ichiryusai.
In 1832, he changed his pseudonym to Ichiryusai.

sen.j: 安政5年没。
sen.e: He died in 1858.
He died in 1858.
He died in 1858.

sen.j: 享年62。
sen.e: Died at the age of 62.
He died at the age of 62.
He died at the age of 62.

sen.j: 友人歌川国貞の筆になる「死に絵」（＝追悼ポートレートのようなもの。本項の画像参照）に辞世の歌が遺る。
sen.e: His friend Kunisada UTAGAWA painted his "Shinie" (something like a portrait for remembrance; refer to the image in this section) with his death poem written on it.
His friend Kunisada UTAGAWA painted his "Shinie" (something like a portrait for remembrance; refer to the image in this section) with his death poem written on it.
His friend Kunisada UTAGAWA painted his "Shinie" (something like a portrait for remembrance; refer to the image in this section) with his death poem written on it.

sen.j: 東路へ筆をのこして旅のそら 西のみ国の名ところを見ん
sen.e: I depart on journey, leaving my brush in the East, to scenic places in the Western country.
I depart on a journey, leaving my brush in the East, to scenic places in the Western country.
I depart on a journey, leaving my brush in the East, to scenic places in the Western country.

sen.j: 「西方浄土の名所を見てまわりたい」と詠っている。
sen.e: He meant, "I want to see scenic places in the Western Pure Land."
He meant, "I want to see scenic places in the Western Pure Land."
He meant, "I want to see scenic places in the Western Pure Land."

sen.j: 死因はコレラだったと伝えられる。
sen.e: The cause of death is said to have been cholera.
The cause of death is said to have been cholera.
The cause of death is said to have been cholera.

sen.j: 歌川広重の作品は、ヨーロッパやアメリカ合衆国では、大胆な構図などとともに、青色、特に藍色の美しさで評価が高い。
sen.e: The works of Hiroshige UTAGAWA are highly appreciated in Europe and the United States of America for its dynamic composition and the beauty of blue color, particularly indigo blue.
The works of Hiroshige UTAGAWA are highly appreciated in Europe and the United States of America for their dynamic composition and the beauty of blue color, particularly indigo blue.
The works of Hiroshige UTAGAWA are highly appreciated in Europe and the United States of America for their dynamic composition and the beauty of blue color, particularly indigo blue.

sen.j: この鮮やかな青は藍（インディゴ）の色であり、欧米では「ジャパンブルー」、あるいはフェルメール・ブルー（ラピスラズリ）になぞらえて「ヒロシゲブルー」とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: This vivid blue is derived from indigo plant and called in Europe and America "Japan Blue" or "Hiroshige Blue" comparing it to Vermeer Blue (lapis lazuli).
This vivid blue is derived from the indigo plant and called in Europe and America "Japan Blue" or "Hiroshige Blue" comparing it to Vermeer Blue (lapis lazuli).
This vivid blue is derived from the indigo plant and called in Europe and America "Japan Blue" or "Hiroshige Blue" comparing it to Vermeer Blue (lapis lazuli).

sen.j: ヒロシゲブルーは、19世紀後半のフランスに発した印象派の画家たちや、アール・ヌーヴォーの芸術家たちに大きな影響をあたえたとされ、当時ジャポニスムの流行を生んだ要因のひとつともされている。
sen.e: Hiroshige Blue is considered to have given a great influence on impressionists and Art Nouveau artists in the late 19th century France and was one of the factors that had generated Japonism then.
Hiroshige Blue is considered to have had a great influence on impressionists and Art Nouveau artists in late 19th century France and was one of the factors that had generated Japonism then.

Hiroshige Blue is considered to have had a great influence on impressionists and Art Nouveau artists originated in late 19th century France and was one of the factors that had led to the prevalence of Japonism then.
sen.cmt: 「発した」「流行」を訳出しました

sen.j: 天保3年（1832年）秋、広重は幕府の行列（御馬進献の使）に加わって上洛（京都まで東海道往復の旅）する機会を得たとされる。
sen.e: In 1832, Hiroshige is said to have obtained a chance to travel back and forth to Kyoto by joining the shogunate procession to present horses to the emperor.
In 1832, Hiroshige is said to have obtained a chance to travel back and forth to Kyoto by joining the shogunate procession to present horses to the emperor.
In 1832, Hiroshige is said to have obtained a chance to travel back and forth to Kyoto by joining the shogunate procession which was the envoy to present horses to the emperor.
sen.cmt: which was the envoyを補完しました

sen.j: 天保4年（1833年）には傑作といわれる『東海道五十三次絵』が生まれた。
sen.e: In 1833, he painted "Tokaido Gojusan-tsugi" (Fifty-three Stations of the Tokaido), which is regarded as his masterpiece.
In 1833, he painted "Tokaido Gojusan-tsugi" (Fifty-three Stations of the Tokaido), which is regarded as his masterpiece.
In 1833, he painted "Tokaido Gojusan-tsugi" (Fifty-three Stations of the Tokaido), which is regarded as his masterpiece.

sen.j: この作品は遠近法が用いられ、風や雨を感じさせる立体的な描写など、絵そのものの良さに加えて、当時の人々があこがれた外の世界を垣間見る手段としても、大変好評を博した。
sen.e: It became very popular as a method to see the outside world that the people of that time yearned to see, in addition to the excellence of the work itself with perspective and a sense of depth effectively representing rain or wind.

In addition to the excellence of the work itself, with perspective and a sense of depth effectively representing rain or wind, it became very popular as a method to see the outside world that the people of that time yearned to see.

In addition to the excellence of the work itself, with perspective and a sense of depth effectively representing rain or wind, it became very popular as a measure to get a glimpse of the outside world that the people of that time yearned to see.
sen.cmt: method to see the outside world→measure to get a glimpse of the outside world

sen.j: なお、つてを頼って幕府の行列に加えてもらったとの伝承が伝わるが、実際には旅行をしていないのではないかという説もある。
sen.e: Meanwhile, there is a theory that in fact he might have not traveled, although a story says that he managed to have joined the shogunate procession using influential connections.
Meanwhile, there is a theory that in fact he might have not traveled, although a story says that he managed to have joined the shogunate procession using influential connections.
Meanwhile, there is a theory that in fact he might have not traveled, although a story says that he managed to have joined the shogunate procession using influential connections.

sen.j: また、司馬江漢の洋画を換骨奪胎して制作したという説もある。
sen.e: There is also a theory that he painted it by modifying oil paintings of Kokan SHIBA.
sen.cmt: 「換骨奪胎」→先人の詩や文章などの着想・形式などを借用し、新味を加えて独自の作品にすること（yahoo辞書）
sen.e: There is also a theory that he painted it by modifying oil paintings of Kokan SHIBA.
There is also a theory that he painted it by modifying oil paintings of Kokan SHIBA.

sen.j: 江戸時代中期には生産力の向上から都市部では学問や遊芸、祭礼・年中行事など町人文化が活性化した。
sen.e: In the middle Edo period, improved productivity in cities activated townsmen culture such as learning, arts for amusement, rites, festivals and seasonal events.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In the middle of the Edo period, improved productivity in cities revitalized townsmen culture such as learning, arts for amusement, rites, festivals and seasonal events.
In the middle of the Edo period, improved productivity in cities revitalized townsmen culture such as learning, arts for amusement, rites, festivals and seasonal events.

sen.j: 幕府直轄領時代の甲斐国甲府城下町（山梨県甲府市）でも江戸後期には華麗な幕絵を飾った盛大な甲府道祖神祭りが行われていた。
sen.e: Kofu Castle Town in Kai Province (Kofu City, Yamanashi Prefecture), then under the direct control of shogunate, also held a grand festival of Doso-jin (traveler's guardian deity) in the late Edo period decorating with splendid banner paintings.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Kofu Castle Town in Kai Province (Kofu City, Yamanashi Prefecture), then under the direct control of the shogunate, also held a grand festival of Doso-jin (traveler's guardian deity) in the late Edo period where it was decorated with splendid banner paintings.

Kofu Castle Town in Kai Province (Kofu City, Yamanashi Prefecture), then under the direct control of the shogunate, also held a grand festival of Doso-jin (traveler's guardian deity) in the late Edo period where it was decorated with splendid banner paintings.

sen.j: 甲府商人の経済力を背景に江戸から広重ら著名な絵師が招かれて幕絵製作を行っている。
sen.e: The economic power of merchants in Kofu enabled them to invite famous painters like Hiroshige from Edo to paint the banners.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The economic power of merchants in Kofu enabled them to invite famous painters like Hiroshige from Edo to paint the banners.
The economic power of merchants in Kofu enabled them to invite famous painters like Hiroshige from Edo to produce the banner paintings.
sen.cmt: to paint the banners→to produce the banner paintings

sen.j: 広重は天保12年（1841年）に甲府緑町一丁目（現若松町）の町人から幕絵製作を依頼され、同年4月には江戸を立ち甲州街道を経て甲府へ向かい、幕絵製作のため滞在している。
sen.e: Upon the request in 1841 of townspeople in 1-chome, Midori-cho, Kofu (now Wakamatsu-cho) to paint the banner, Hiroshige left Edo for Kofu via Koshu-kaido Road in April of the same year and stayed there working on it.

Upon the request in 1841 of townspeople in 1-chome, Midori-cho, Kofu (now Wakamatsu-cho) to paint the banner, Hiroshige left Edo for Kofu via Koshu-kaido Road in April of the same year and stayed there working on it.

Upon the request in 1841 of townspeople in 1-chome, Midori-cho, Kofu (now Wakamatsu-cho) to paint the banner, Hiroshige left Edo for Kofu via Koshu-kaido Road in May of that year and stayed there working on it.
sen.cmt: in April of the same year→in May of that year（西暦に変換しました）

sen.j: この時の記録が『甲州日記』（「天保十二年丑年卯月日々の記」）で、江戸から旅した際に道中や滞在中の写生や日記を書き付けられている。
sen.e: "Koshu Nikki" (Record of the Days in April 1841, Year of the Ox) is a record of that time, with sketches and diaries written during his trip from Edo and stay in Kofu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処「天保十二年」→1841年「滞在中」→「甲府滞在中」と補足して訳しました。
sen.e: "Koshu Nikki" (Record of the Days in April 1841, Year of the Ox) is a record of that time, with sketches and diaries written during his trip from Edo and stay in Kofu.
"Koshu Nikki" (Record of the Days in May 1841, Year of the Ox) is a record of that time, with sketches and diaries written during his trip from Edo and stay in Kofu.

sen.j: 現在の八王子市から見た高尾山、甲府市内から見た富士山や市内の甲斐善光寺、身延町の富士川など甲州の名所が太さの異なる筆と墨で描かれている。
sen.e: It includes sketches of scenic places in Koshu, such as Mt. Takao viewed from current Hachioji City, Mt. Fuji viewed from Kofu City, Kai Zenko-ji Temple there and the Fuji-gawa River in Minobu-cho, drawn in black ink with brushes of different thickness.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It includes sketches of scenic places in Koshu, such as Mt. Takao viewed from current Hachioji City, Mt. Fuji viewed from Kofu City, Kai Zenko-ji Temple and the Fuji-gawa River in Minobu-cho, drawn in black ink with brushes of different thickness.

It includes sketches of scenic places in Koshu, such as Mt. Takao viewed from current Hachioji City, Mt. Fuji viewed from Kofu City, Kai Zenko-ji Temple there and the Fuji-gawa River in Minobu-cho, drawn in black ink with brushes of different thickness.
sen.cmt: 翻訳者の訳としました

sen.j: 広重の作品研究に利用されているほか、甲府での芝居見物や接待された料理屋の記録など、近世甲府城下町の実態を知る記録資料としても重視されている。
sen.e: It is used for the study of Hiroshige's works and also regarded as an important record of the actual situation of Kofu Castle Town in the Edo period, for its descriptions about a play viewing in Kofu, eating in a restaurant, and so on.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処「天保十二年」→1841年「近世」→日本史では、安土桃山・江戸時代を指す（goo辞書）ここでは江戸時代のことなので、"Edo period"と訳しました。
sen.e: It is used for the study of Hiroshige's works and also regarded as an important record of the actual situation of Kofu Castle Town in the Edo period, for its descriptions about a play viewing in Kofu, eating in a restaurant, and so on.

It is used for the study of Hiroshige's works and also regarded as an important record of the actual situation of Kofu Castle Town in the Edo period, for its descriptions about a play viewing in Kofu, a restaurant where he was entertained, and so on.
sen.cmt: 「接待された」を訳出しました

sen.j: 日記によれば広重は同年4月5日に甲府へ到着し、滞在中は甲府町民から歓迎され句会や芝居見物などを行っている。
sen.e: According to the diary, Hiroshige arrived at Kofu on April 5 of the same year and enjoyed a haiku gathering, play, and so on during his stay, welcomed by townspeople of Kofu.
According to the diary, Hiroshige arrived at Kofu on April 5th of the same year and enjoyed a haiku gathering, play and so on during his stay, and was welcomed by the townspeople of Kofu.
According to the diary, Hiroshige arrived at Kofu on May 25 of that year and enjoyed a haiku gathering, play and so on during his stay, and was welcomed by the townspeople of Kofu.
sen.cmt: 西暦に変換しましたthe same year→that year25th→25

sen.j: 日記は一時中断して11月からはじまっており、この間には暮絵は完成した。
sen.e: The diary was then interrupted and resumed in November, during which interruption the banner paintings were completed.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The diary was then interrupted and resumed in November, during this interruption the banner paintings were completed.
The diary was then interrupted and resumed in December, during which interruption the banner paintings were completed.
sen.cmt: 西暦に変換しましたthe same year→that year

sen.j: 手付金は5両であったという。
sen.e: The advance money is said to have been 5 ryo (ryo is a currency unit).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The advance money is said to have been 5 ryo (ryo is a currency unit).
The advance money is said to have been 5 ryo (ryo is a currency unit).

sen.j: 幕絵は東海道の名所を描いた39枚の作品で、甲府柳町に飾られたという。
sen.e: These banner paintings of 39 scenic places along the Tokai-do Road were displayed in Yanagi-machi, Kofu.
These banner paintings of 39 scenic places along the Tokai-do Road were displayed in Yanagi-machi, Kofu.
These banner paintings of 39 scenic places along the Tokai-do Road were displayed in Yanagi-machi, Kofu.

sen.j: 日記の中断期間中は幕絵制作に専念していた可能性や、制作のためにいったん江戸で戻っていた可能性などが考えられている。
sen.e: During the interruption of the diary, he is considered to have dedicated himself in painting the banner, or temporarily have returned to Edo to work on it.
During the interruption of the diary, he is considered to have dedicated himself to painting the banner, or temporarily have returned to Edo to work on it.
During the interruption of the diary, he is considered to have dedicated himself to painting the banner, or temporarily have returned to Edo to work on it.

sen.j: 広重の製作した幕絵は現存しているものが少ないが、山梨県立博物館には2枚の幕絵が所蔵されており、甲府市の旧家には下絵が現存している。
sen.e: Among the banner paintings completed by Hiroshige, only a few have been preserved till the present day; two of them are owned by Yamanashi Prefectural Museum and a preliminary sketch has been retained by an old family in Kofu City.

Among the banner paintings completed by Hiroshige, only a few have been preserved till the present day; two of them are owned by Yamanashi Prefectural Museum and a preliminary sketch has been retained by an old family in Kofu City.

Among the banner paintings completed by Hiroshige, only a few have been preserved till the present day; two of them are owned by Yamanashi Prefectural Museum and a preliminary sketch has been retained by an old family in Kofu City.

sen.j: また、幕絵以外にも甲府町人から依頼された屏風絵や襖絵などを手がけており、甲府商家の大木コレクション（山梨県立博物館所蔵）には作品の一部が残されている。
sen.e: In addition to the banner paintings, he also completed paintings on folding screen and sliding door upon the request of townspeople of Kofu and a part of them has been preserved by a mercantile house of Kofu, Oki Collection (owned by Yamanashi Prefectural Museum).

In addition to the banner paintings, he also completed paintings on folding screens and sliding doors upon the request of the townspeople of Kofu and a part of them has been preserved by a mercantile house of Kofu, Oki Collection (owned by Yamanashi Prefectural Museum).

In addition to the banner paintings, he also completed paintings on folding screens and sliding doors upon the request of the townspeople of Kofu and a part of them has been preserved by a mercantile house of Kofu, Oki Collection (owned by Yamanashi Prefectural Museum).

sen.j: 日記は甲府滞在記録のほか甲斐名所のスケッチも記されており、一部は『不二三十六景』において活かされている。
sen.e: The diary also contains sketches of scenic places in Kai Province in addition to the records of his stay in Kofu, and a part of the sketches was used to paint "Fuji Sanjurokkei" (Thirty-six Views of Mt. Fuji).

The diary also contains sketches of scenic places in Kai Province in addition to the records of his stay in Kofu, and a part of the sketches was used to paint "Fuji Sanjurokkei" (Thirty-six Views of Mt. Fuji).

The diary also contains sketches of scenic places in Kai Province in addition to the records of his stay in Kofu, and a part of the sketches was utilized in the paint "Fuji Sanjurokkei" (Thirty-six Views of Mt. Fuji).

sen.j: 『甲斐志料集成』などに収録され知られていたが、原本は関東大震災で焼失している。
sen.e: It was known as contained in "Kai Shiryo Shusei" (Collected Materials of Kai Provincial History), but the original book was lost in the Great Kanto Earthquake.
It was known to be contained in "Kai Shiryo Shusei" (Collected Materials of Kai Provincial History), but the original book was lost in the Great Kanto Earthquake.
It was known to be contained in "Kai Shiryo Shusei" (Collected Materials of Kai Provincial History), but the original book was lost in the Great Kanto Earthquake.

sen.j: 発見された写生帳は和紙19枚を綴じたもので、縦19.6cm横13.1cm。
sen.e: The discovered sketchbook consists of 19 Japanese papers, 19.6 cm long and 13.1 cm wide.
The discovered sketchbook consists of 19 Japanese papers, 19.6 cm long and 13.1 cm wide.
The discovered sketchbook consists of 19 Japanese papers, 19.6 cm long and 13.1 cm wide.

sen.j: 3代広重が1894年に（明治27年）死去した直後の海外に流出したとされる。
sen.e: It is said to have been taken abroad immediately after the death of Hiroshige the third in 1894.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is said to have been taken abroad immediately after the death of Hiroshige the third in 1894.
It is said to have been taken abroad immediately after the death of Hiroshige the third in 1894.

sen.j: 1925年にイギリス人研究家エドワード・ストレンジが著書で紹介して以来、行方不明であった。
sen.e: In 1925, English researcher Edward F. STRANGE introduced it in his book, but then it went missing.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In 1925, English researcher Edward F. STRANGE introduced it in his book, but then it went missing.
In 1925, English researcher Edward F. STRANGE introduced it in his book, but then it went missing.

sen.j: 2005年にロンドンのオークションでアメリカ合衆国国民が落札、栃木県那珂川町 (栃木県)馬頭広重美術館の学芸員が本物と鑑定した。
sen.e: In 2005, a citizen of the United States of America won it in an auction held in London, and a curator of Nakagawa-machi Bato Hiroshige Museum of Art in Tochigi Prefecture judged it as genuine.
In 2005, a citizen of the United States of America won it in an auction held in London, and a curator of Nakagawa-machi Bato Hiroshige Museum of Art in Tochigi Prefecture judged it as genuine.
In 2005, a citizen of the United States of America won it in an auction held in London, and a curator of Nakagawa-machi Bato Hiroshige Museum of Art in Tochigi Prefecture judged it as genuine.

sen.j: 約80年ぶりに発見されたのである（2006年9月5日付朝日新聞）。
sen.e: It was discovered after almost 80 years (Asahi Shinbun newspaper dated September 5, 2006).
It was discovered after almost 80 years (Asahi Shinbun newspaper dated September 5, 2006).
It was discovered after almost 80 years (Asahi Shinbun newspaper dated September 5, 2006).

sen.j: その後、嘉永（1848年）頃から単に立斎と称している。
sen.e: Later, around 1848, he started to call himself simply Ryusai.
Later, around 1848, he started to call himself simply Ryusai.
Later, around 1848, he started to call himself simply Ryusai.

sen.j: 版画が盛んになって、浮世絵師が版画家になってからは、彩筆をとって紙や絹に立派に書き上げることの出来るものが少なくなったが、広重は版画とはまた趣の違った素晴らしい絵を残している。
sen.e: As woodblock printing became popular, Ukiyoe artists became printmakers, rarely having a big work to paint on paper or silk with brushes, but Hiroshige left superb paintings that had a different charm from prints.

As woodblock printing became popular, Ukiyoe artists became printmakers, rarely having large amounts of work to paint on paper or silk with brushes, but Hiroshige left superb paintings that had a different charm from prints.

As woodblock printing became popular, Ukiyoe artists became printmakers and few could finely paint on paper or silk with brushes, but Hiroshige left superb paintings that had a different charm from prints.
sen.cmt: 中間部を改変しました

sen.j: なお、遠近法は印象派画家、特にフィンセント・ファン・ゴッホ（1853年-1890年）に影響を与えたことで良く知られているが、もともと西洋絵画から浮世絵師が取り入れた様式であり、先人としては葛飾北斎や、歌川の始祖歌川豊春（1735年-1814年）の浮絵にみられる。
sen.e: The perspective is known to have influenced impressionists, particularly Vincent Van GOGH (1853 - 1890), but it was originally a technique that Ukiyoe artists had adopted from Western paintings, and can be observed in paintings of earlier artists such as Hokusai KATSUSHIKA and Toyoharu UTAGAWA (1735 - 1814), the founder of Utagawa school.

The perspective is known to have influenced impressionists, particularly Vincent Van GOGH (1853 - 1890), but it was originally a technique that Ukiyoe artists had adopted from Western paintings, and can be observed in paintings of earlier artists such as Hokusai KATSUSHIKA and Toyoharu UTAGAWA (1735 - 1814), the founder of Utagawa school.

The perspective is known to have influenced impressionists, particularly Vincent Van GOGH (1853 - 1890), but it was originally a technique that Ukiyoe artists had adopted from Western paintings, and can be observed in uki-e (perspective pictures) by earlier artists such as Hokusai KATSUSHIKA and Toyoharu UTAGAWA (1735 - 1814), the founder of Utagawa school.

sen.j: 文久年間（1861年から1863年）の「江戸日本橋南之絵図」によると、日本橋大鋸（おおが）町（現在の京橋）に広重の住居があり、西隣には狩野永徳の旧居が印刷されている。
sen.e: According to 'Picture of Southern Nihonbashi in Edo' of Bunkyu era (from 1861 to 1863), Hiroshige's residence was located in Oga-cho, Nihonbashi (now Kyobashi) next to the former residence of Eitoku KANO in the west.

According to 'Picture of Southern Nihonbashi in Edo' of Bunkyu era (from 1861 to 1863), Hiroshige's residence was located in Oga-cho, Nihonbashi (now Kyobashi) next to the former residence of Eitoku KANO in the west.

According to 'Picture of Southern Nihonbashi in Edo' of Bunkyu era (from 1861 to 1863), Hiroshige's residence was located in Oga-cho, Nihonbashi (now Kyobashi) next to the former residence of Eitoku KANO in the west.

sen.j: その後、京橋よりに道路5つほど先の、常磐町に移転したようである。
sen.e: He seems to have moved later to Tokiwa-cho, five blocks ahead from Kyobashi.
He seems to have moved later to Tokiwa-cho, five blocks before Kyobashi.
He seems to have moved later to Tokiwa-cho, five blocks ahead to Kyobashi.

sen.j: 辞世の句は、東路（あづまぢ）に筆をのこして旅の空 西のみくにの名所を見む であるというが、のちの人の作ではないかという見解もある。
sen.e: His death poem is said to have been "I depart on journey, leaving my brush in the East, to scenic places in the Western country," but some people think that someone else might have made it.
sen.cmt: 辞世の句の部分は、原文に『』がありませんが、不自然になるので""でくくりました。
sen.e: His death poem is said to have been "I depart on a journey, leaving my brush in the East, to scenic places in the Western country", but some people think that someone else might have made it.
His death poem is said to have been "I depart on a journey, leaving my brush in the East, to scenic places in the Western country", but some people think that someone else might have made it.

sen.j: 明治15年（1882年）4月（広重の死後24年目）、門人たちが、墨江須崎村の秋葉神社に碑を建立したが、第二次世界大戦の東京大空襲により破壊され、現在は残っていない。
sen.e: In April 1882 (24 years after the death of Hiroshige), his disciples established a monument at Akiba Shrine in Susaki Village, Suminoe, but it was destroyed in the Second World War and nothing remains now.

In April 1882 (24 years after the death of Hiroshige), his disciples established a monument at Akiba Shrine in Susaki Village, Suminoe, but it was destroyed in the Second World War and nothing remains now.

In April 1882 (24 years after the death of Hiroshige), his disciples established a monument at Akiba Shrine in Susaki Village, Suminoe, but it was destroyed in Great Tokyo Air Raids in the Second World War and nothing remains now.
sen.cmt: 「東京大空襲」を訳出しました

sen.j: 流行の疫病（コレラ）により安政5年（1858年）9月6日65歳で没。
sen.e: He died from an epidemic (cholera) in September 6, 1858 at the age of 65.
He died from an epidemic (cholera) on September 6, 1858 at the age of 65.
He died from an epidemic (cholera) on October 12, 1858 at the age of 65.

sen.j: 墓所は禅宗東岳寺。
sen.e: His tomb is at Togaku-ji Temple of the Zen sect.
His tomb is at Togaku-ji Temple of the Zen sect.
His tomb is at Togaku-ji Temple of the Zen sect.

sen.j: 各所で所蔵されるが、光線による劣化があるため常時展示はしていないことが多い。

sen.j: 藤懸静也によると、二代目廣重は広重の門人で俗称を森田鎮平と云い、号を宣重という。
sen.e: According to Shizuya FUJIKAKE, Hiroshige the second was a disciple of Hiroshige commonly called Chinpei MORITA whose pseudonym was Nobushige.
According to Shizuya FUJIKAKE, Hiroshige the second was a disciple of Hiroshige commonly called Chinpei MORITA whose pseudonym was Nobushige.
According to Shizuya FUJIKAKE, Hiroshige the second was a disciple of Hiroshige and commonly called Chinpei MORITA whose pseudonym was Nobushige.

sen.j: 初代の養女お辰（16歳）と結婚したが、のち慶応元年（1865年）妻22歳の時、離縁となっている。
sen.e: He married Otatsu, 16-year-old adopted daughter of Hiroshige the first, but later divorced her in 1865 when she was 22.
sen.cmt: 「初代の」→「初代廣重の」と補足して訳しました。
sen.e: He married Otatsu, a 16-year-old adopted daughter of Hiroshige the first, but later divorced her in 1865 when she was 22.
He married Otatsu, a 16-year-old adopted daughter of Hiroshige the first, but later divorced her in 1865 when she was 22.

sen.j: その後、しばしば横浜市に出向いて絵を売り込み、外国貿易が次第に盛んになっている時期「茶箱廣重」の名で外国人に知られた。
sen.e: Then he often went to Yokohama City to sell his works, and as foreign trade gradually increased, he became known to foreigners as "Hiroshige of tea box" (because he painted labels attached to tea boxes used for shipping).
sen.cmt: 「茶箱廣重」→輸出用の茶箱に添付するラベルを描いたことから。説明を入れました。（http://www.kaikou.city.yokohama.jp/journal/096/02-2.htmlなど参照）
sen.e: After this, he often went to Yokohama City to sell his works, and as foreign trade gradually increased, he became known to foreigners as "Hiroshige of tea box" (because he painted labels attached to tea boxes used for shipping).

After this, he often went to Yokohama City to sell his works, and as foreign trade gradually increased, he became known to foreigners as "Hiroshige of tea box" (because he painted labels attached to tea boxes used for shipping).

sen.j: また、「喜齋立祥」の画号を用いて制作したがその中で、花を主題にした一種の景色画、『三十六花撰』の出来栄えがよく、版元の求めに応じ、大錦判の竪繪に作った。
sen.e: Among his works created in the name of 'Kisai Rissho,' "Sanju-rokkasen" (Selected 36 Flowers), a kind of landscape painting with the theme of flowers, was superb and made in a large vertical type of colored woodblock print upon the request of publishers.

Among his works created in the name of 'Kisai Rissho,' "Sanju-rokkasen" (Selected 36 Flowers), a kind of landscape painting with the theme of flowers, was superb and made on a large vertical type of colored woodblock print upon the request of publishers.

Among his works created in the name of 'Kisai Rissho,' "Sanju-rokkasen" (Selected 36 Flowers), a kind of landscape painting with the theme of flowers, was superb and made on a large vertical type of colored woodblock print upon the request of publishers.

sen.j: なお、『名所江戸百景』のなかの「赤坂桐畑雨中夕けい」で秀逸な絵を残しており、初代の「赤坂桐畑」よりも構図、色彩ともに評価が高い。
sen.e: He also left an excellent painting in a series "Meisho Edo Hyakkei," 'Akasaka Kiribata Uchu Yukei' (View of the Kiribata [Paulownia Imperiales] Trees at Akasaka on a Rainy Evening) that is highly appreciated for its composition and colors, more than 'Akasaka Kiribata' painted by Hiroshige the first.
sen.cmt: 「初代の」→「初代廣重の」と補足して訳しました。
sen.e: He also left an excellent painting in a series "Meisho Edo Hyakkei," 'Akasaka Kiribata Uchu Yukei' (View of the Kiribata [Paulownia Imperiales] Trees at Akasaka on a Rainy Evening) that is highly appreciated for its composition and colors, more than 'Akasaka Kiribata' painted by Hiroshige the first.

Among "Meisho Edo Hyakkei" series, he left an excellent painting 'Akasaka Kiribata Uchu Yukei' (View of the Kiribata [Paulownia Imperiales] Trees at Akasaka on a Rainy Evening) that is highly appreciated for its composition and colors, more than 'Akasaka Kiribata' painted by Hiroshige the first.

sen.j: 三代目は門人の重政（1845年-1894年）で俗称は後藤寅吉である。
sen.e: Hiroshige the third was one of disciples Shigemasa (1845 - 1894), commonly called Torakichi GOTO.
sen.cmt: 「三代目」→「三代目廣重」と補足して訳しました。
sen.e: Hiroshige the third was one of the disciples of Shigemasa (1845 - 1894), commonly called Torakichi GOTO.
Hiroshige the third was Shigemasa (1845 - 1894) who was one of disciples and commonly called Torakichi GOTO.

sen.j: 離縁後のお辰を妻とした。
sen.e: He married Otatsu after she got divorced.
He married Otatsu after she got divorced.
He married Otatsu after she got divorced.

sen.j: 号は一笑齋。
sen.e: His pseudonym was Isshosai.
His pseudonym was Isshosai.
His pseudonym was Isshosai.

sen.j: 四代目（菊地喜一郎）は、三代目夫人お辰と清水清風らが相談して、四代目広重を襲名させた。
sen.e: Hiroshige the fourth was Kiichiro KIKUCHI, whose succession of the name was decided by a consultation between Otatsu, wife of Hiroshige the third and Seifu SHIMIZU.
Hiroshige the fourth was Kiichiro KIKUCHI, whose succession of the name was decided by a consultation between Otatsu, wife of Hiroshige the third and Seifu SHIMIZU.
Hiroshige the fourth was Kiichiro KIKUCHI, whose succession of the name was decided by a consultation between Otatsu, wife of Hiroshige the third and Seifu SHIMIZU.

sen.j: 菊地家は安藤家と親しかったためである。
sen.e: It was because the Kikuchi family was close to the Ando family.
It was because the Kikuchi family was close to the Ando family.
It was because the Kikuchi family was close to the Ando family.

sen.j: 最初は版画を制作し、武者絵などを多く書いたが、後に書家となった。
sen.e: He first created woodblock prints, mainly on warriors, but later became a calligrapher.
He first created woodblock prints, mainly of warriors, but later became a calligrapher.
He first created woodblock prints, mainly of warriors, but later became a calligrapher.

sen.j: 喜一郎は浮世絵に関する著作を出版している。
sen.e: Kiichiro published a book about Ukiyoe.
